pr_title: PLANNER-1003 Migrate tests to JUnit 5 API

timeline.bodyText: How could this be possible? If both had to throw, then the original test would never have reached the second one.
timeline.author: triceo

replies.bodyText: jUnit4 does not care - if at least one of the expressions throws an exception, the test passes. Now the test can actually work.
replies.author: rsynek

replies.bodyText: Yes that is the drawback of the JUnit 4 approach. The test will pass no matter the line at which the exception is thrown. In this case, both statements throw but the second one was never reached.
replies.author: yurloc

timeline.bodyText: Wouldn't it be easier to just fix it, instead of adding the FIXME? :-)
timeline.author: triceo

replies.bodyText:
It was easier to add the fixme note than to make a decision immediately.
I've just reviewed the test and I think I can fix it. Thanks for pointing it out!
replies.author: yurloc

timeline.bodyText: Should this be rather org.junit.jupiter.api.Assertions (or Assertions from the AssertJ library)? There are more such imports in other test classes.
timeline.author: rsynek

replies.bodyText:
I may be wrong here, but I ran into something similar elsewhere. JUnit 5, in combination with Surefire, would just silently skip some tests.
See https://stackoverflow.com/questions/36970384/surefire-is-not-picking-up-junit-5-tests for more.
replies.author: triceo

replies.bodyText:
Assertions are out of scope of this PR although it makes sense to completely drop dependency on JUnit 4. Maybe a simple regex on the import statement would solve that but I really want to avoid scope creep.
JUnit 5 migration tip:

Note that you may continue to use assertion methods from org.junit.Assert or any other assertion library ...
replies.author: yurloc

timeline.message: Fix AbstractPhaseTest names and group them using dynamicContainer()
Fix AbstractPhaseTest names and group them using dynamicContainer()

timeline.bodyText:
Since the check is made here in the factory method, we have 1 skipped test for each turtle test class instead of skipping individual dynamic tests.
I just realized we can improve this even further by simply returning an empty stream from the test factory if turtle tests are not enabled. I think this is a nice use of the dynamic test feature.
timeline.author: yurloc

replies.bodyText:
Thank you for pointing out. Makes sense.
Make sure that the skipped tests count comparison take this into account and ignores that difference - that's fine.
